section_1_key_concepts.overview: This topic covers the key practices of Christianity including worship, prayer, sacraments, and the role of the Church in the local community and worldwide.

key_terms.definition: A formal, structured form of worship following a set pattern
key_terms.importance: Used in Catholic and Anglican churches

key_terms.definition: A holy ritual through which believers receive God's grace
A sacrament of initiation into the Christian faith using water
key_terms.importance: Practised by almost all Christian denominations

key_terms.definition: A sacrament remembering the Last Supper — bread and wine represent Christ's body and blood
key_terms.importance: Central act of worship for most Christians

key_terms.definition: A journey to a holy place for spiritual reasons

learning_objectives: Describe different forms of Christian worship
Analyse the role of the Church in the community
Evaluate the importance of prayer and pilgrimage

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Forms of Worship
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Liturgical worship follows a set order of service (e.g., Catholic Mass). Non-liturgical worship is more informal and spontaneous (e.g., Quaker meetings). Private worship is individual prayer and Bible study at home. Each form helps Christians connect with God differently.
key_points: Private = individual prayer, meditation, Bible reading
All forms aim to worship and communicate with God

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Sacraments: Baptism and Eucharist
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Baptism: Infant baptism (Catholic, Anglican) welcomes babies into the Church — parents and godparents make promises. Believers' baptism (Baptist) is full immersion for those old enough to choose. Eucharist: Catholics believe bread and wine literally become Christ's body and blood (transubstantiation). Protestants see it as symbolic remembrance.
key_points: Infant baptism = promises made on child's behalf
Believers' baptism = personal choice, full immersion
Transubstantiation = Catholic belief in literal change
Protestants = symbolic remembrance of Last Supper

section_3_worked_examples.question: 'Prayer is the most important Christian practice.' Evaluate this statement (12 marks)
step_by_step: Agree: Prayer is direct communication with God. Jesus taught the Lord's Prayer (Matthew 6:9-13), showing its importance. Many Christians pray daily — it strengthens their relationship with God.
Agree: Prayer brings comfort in difficult times. Philippians 4:6 — 'Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer... present your requests to God.'
Disagree: Some Christians would argue worship is more important as it involves community. Hebrews 10:25 — 'Not giving up meeting together.'
Disagree: Others might say charity work (agape love) is the most important practice — 'Faith without deeds is dead' (James 2:26).
Conclusion: While prayer is fundamental, many Christians would argue it is most effective when combined with worship and action.
section_3_worked_examples.answer: Balanced evaluation using scripture and different Christian viewpoints

foundation.question: What is a sacrament?
foundation.correct_answer: A holy ritual through which believers receive God's grace
foundation.explanation: Sacraments are sacred acts instituted by Jesus

foundation.question: Which type of baptism involves full immersion in water?
foundation.explanation: Believers' baptism (e.g., Baptist churches) involves adults choosing to be fully immersed

higher.question: 'The Eucharist is the most important sacrament.' Evaluate this statement with reference to Christianity (12 marks)
higher.correct_answer: Balanced argument considering Catholic vs Protestant views, with scripture references and a justified conclusion
higher.explanation: Must include multiple viewpoints and use theological terminology

command_words.meaning: Consider different viewpoints, use evidence, make a judgement
Give two developed points with reasoning

common_mistakes: Not referring to specific Christian denominations
Giving opinions without backing them with scripture

revision_checklist: I can describe 3 forms of worship
I can compare infant and believers' baptism
I can explain the Eucharist with denomination differences

answers.model_answer: A sacrament is a holy ritual or ceremony through which Christians believe they receive God's grace. Catholics recognise 7 sacraments while most Protestants recognise 2 (Baptism and Eucharist).
answers.examiner_tip: Always mention denomination differences where relevant
